message_1: A hospital is studying the survival times of patients diagnosed with a certain disease. They found that the survival times follow an exponential distribution with a mean of 5 months. What is the probability that a patient diagnosed with this disease will survive for more than 3 months?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we need to use the exponential distribution formula. The probability density function (pdf) of an exponential distribution is given by:

f(t) = (1/μ) * e^(-t/μ)

where t is the survival time, μ is the mean survival time (in this case, 5 months), and e is the base of the natural logarithm (approximately 2.71828).

To find the probability that a patient will survive for more than 3 months, we need to find the complement of the probability that they will survive for 3 months or less. This can be found using the cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the exponential distribution, which is given by:

F(t) = 1 - e^(-t/μ)

The probability that a patient will survive for 3 months or less is:

F(3) = 1 - e^(-3/5)

Now, we can calculate the probability that a patient will survive for more than 3 months by finding the complement of F(3):

P(T > 3) = 1 - F(3)

P(T > 3) = 1 - (1 - e^(-3/5))

P(T > 3) = e^(-3/5)

Now, we can plug in the values and calculate the probability:

P(T > 3) ≈ e^(-3/5) ≈ 2.71828^(-0.6) ≈ 0.5493

So, the probability that a patient diagnosed with this disease will survive for more than 3 months is approximately 0.5493, or 54.93%.
